abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Jharia Mine Fire
            Control Technical Assistance Project for India was
            satisfactory. The project achieved its major objectives, its
            impact on institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, it is important to develop
            a realistic project implementation time schedule.
            Procurement of services and goods prior to loan
            effectiveness can obviate serious delays at the outset of
            the project and credit extensions necessitated to simply
            complete original scopes of work. In addition, a clear
            understanding by borrowers of local and ICB procurement
            procedures is critical prior to loan effectiveness. Second,
            the inter-phasing of borrower data collection, consultant
            services, and equipment procurement/field investigations is
            critical to avoid interruptions in technical assistance
            inputs and scheduling. Finally, in coal-producing countries
            world-wide, it is important to develop a clear and effective
            policy, regulatory, and institutional arrangement for
            environmental or social management. Also, there is a need
            for and benefit of fiscal policies making provisions of
            funds for environmental and social mitigation programs
            necessitated by the impact of historically uncontrolled
            mining activities.
